inputs.selection_motivation: The link from ust30y to us_inflation is weak because yields are driven by inflation, not vice versa, and lacks a clear catalyst window, making it the least credible influence among current links.

prioritized_link.motivation: Long‑term U.S. yields reflect expectations of future economic conditions; a steepening 30‑year curve signals a slowdown that typically precedes rises in unemployment claims, so the 30‑year yield should be modeled as a driver of US unemployment claims.

source_node.query: ((US OR United States OR US Treasury OR US Treasury bond OR US 30-year Treasury OR US 30Y Treasury OR US 30-year Treasury bond OR US 30-year Treasury yield OR US 30Y Treasury yield) OR (30-year Treasury OR 30-year Treasury bond OR 30-year Treasury bond yield OR 30-year Treasury yield OR 30Y Treasury OR 30Y Treasury bond OR 30Y Treasury bond yield)) AND (yield OR yields OR bond OR bonds OR Treasury OR Treasury bond OR Treasury bonds OR 30-year OR 30y OR 30 year) AND (news OR update OR analysis OR report OR market OR trend OR outlook OR forecast OR commentary)

source_node.fundamental_analysis:
The 30‑year fixed‑rate mortgage market in the U.S. is currently anchored to the 10‑yr Treasury yield (ust10y) through a chain of monetary policy transmission: Fed policy → Fed funds rate → ust10y → term premium → mortgage rate (LF0UUL917). The Fed’s September 2024 rate cuts have not yet produced a lasting decline in mortgage rates, which have hovered near 7 % since then, with the latest average at 6.548 % as of August 27 2025, up 2 bp from the prior day and down 8 bp from a week earlier (LF0UUL917). Fed policy, inflation expectations, the national debt burden, loan demand, and the Fed’s balance‑sheet contraction are the primary drivers keeping rates elevated (LF0UUL917). In this framework, the 10‑yr Treasury yield (ust10y) is the canonical handle that directly influences mortgage rates, so the view is mapped as us_mortgage_rates (positive) → ust10y (LF0UUL917).  

The base‑case projection for mortgage rates is a stable 6.8–7.2 % band through 2026, reflecting the persistence of the current policy stance and the limited impact of recent Fed actions (LF0UUL917). The next Fed policy meeting on September 16‑17 2025 and any subsequent change in the Treasury 10‑yr yield will be the primary catalysts that could shift the regime (LF0UUL917).
source_node.executive_summary: U.S. 30‑year fixed‑rate mortgage rates (us_mortgage_rates) have stabilized around 6.55 % as of late August 2025, a modest 2 bp uptick from the prior day and 8 bp decline from a week earlier, driven by the 10‑yr Treasury yield (ust10y) under the current Fed stance (LF0UUL917). The canonical handle mapping is us_mortgage_rates → ust10y, and the projected 6.8–7.2 % band through 2026 is a direct function of the expected ust10y trajectory under the prevailing monetary regime (LF0UUL917). The primary catalyst window is the Fed policy meeting on 16‑17 September 2025 and any subsequent shift in ust10y, which could pivot the mortgage rate regime (LF0UUL917). Key risk is a Fed policy reversal or unexpected inflation that could lift ust10y and compress the term premium, pushing rates above the 7.2 % ceiling (LF0UUL917). Watch signals over the next 3–6 months are the Fed meeting 16‑17 September 2025, ust10y evolution, CPI/Inflation releases, and loan‑demand indicators such as credit‑card utilization and housing‑market activity (LF0UUL917).
source_node.name: US 30Y Treasury Yield

source_node.drivers: DXY will fall 200 bp to 95.8 by Aug 31 (Z7O1DCHS7). This is driven by an 89 % probability of a 25‑bp Fed cut in September (Z7O1DCHS7) and a 57‑bp steepening of the 2‑yr/10‑yr Treasury spread (Z7O1DCHS7); the tariff announcement Aug 29‑31 also pushes DXY down 200 bp but Fed easing offsets short‑term support (Z7O1DCHS7). Over the next 3‑6 months DXY is expected to decline 0.8‑1.5 % (FAN5RYW6T)(Z7O1DCHS7). PCE > 3 % on Aug 30 or NFP > expected on Aug 31 could lift DXY 50‑100 bp (7XH2DKEKV), and flattening of the 2‑yr/10‑yr spread below 30 bp could also lift DXY 50‑100 bp (7XH2DKEKV). Fed policy reversal or unexpected inflation could support DXY (7XH2DKEKV). Watch signals include Aug 30 PCE, Aug 31 NFP, tariff announcement Aug 29‑31, and the 2‑yr/10‑yr Treasury spread (Z7O1DCHS7)(7XH2DKEKV).
source_node.medium_analysis: S&P 500 concentration at 40 % (spx) (FAN5RYW6T) magnifies downside risk if tech earnings weaken (FAN5RYW6T). Weak employment growth in May‑July (us_employment_growth) (FAN5RYW6T) signals a potential September Fed cut (fed_policy) (FAN5RYW6T). Sticky inflation with CPI at 2.7 % YoY (us_cpi) and core PCE at 2.9 % YoY (us_core_cpi) (FAN5RYW6T) keeps the Fed in a position to keep rates high, compressing tech margins (FAN5RYW6T). Tariffs feeding into CPI (us_tariff_policy) (FAN5RYW6T) add cost pressure (FAN5RYW6T). The causal chain: weak labor → Fed cut → lower rates → higher borrowing costs → tech earnings pressure → spx drop due to concentration (FAN5RYW6T). Catalyst window: September 5 payrolls (9/5/2025) (FAN5RYW6T), September 12 CPI release (9/12/2025) (FAN5RYW6T), September 20 Fed meeting (9/20/2025) (FAN5RYW6T), Q3 earnings Oct‑Nov 2025 (FAN5RYW6T). Base case: potential decline of several percent in spx over 3–6 months if tech earnings weaken, Fed cuts, inflation remains sticky (FAN5RYW6T). Alternative: if tech earnings hold, Fed holds rates, inflation eases, spx could remain flat or modestly gain (FAN5RYW6T). Key risks: positive CPI < 2 % (FAN5RYW6T), tech earnings rebound (FAN5RYW6T), Fed hike (FAN5RYW6T). Watch signals: Q3 earnings, Fed minutes, CPI, payrolls (FAN5RYW6T). Confidence moderate.
